Q.   Dr. Cummings, good morning.  Could you introduce yourself to the jury, please.

A.   Sure.  I'm Kenneth Michael Cummings, and I'm a professor in the department of psychiatry at the Medical University of South Carolina in Charleston, South Carolina.

Q.   And, Dr. Cummings, we have a slide on the topics covered this morning including Lamar Danielson's addiction to cigarettes containing nicotine; Philip Morris' marketing of Marlboro cigarettes; and the defendant's concealment and false health controversy, including what Philip Morris and its coconspirators knew from 1953 to 1999 and what they concealed, what they said publicly and through their ads, how it relates to Mr. Danielson's addiction, why it matters in this case. Does that fairly summarize the opinions you'll be giving in court?

A.   It does.

Q.   And can you tell the jury a little bit about yourself in terms of your current work?

A.   Sure.  As I said, I'm a professor in the School of Medicine in the department of psychiatry at the Medical University of South Carolina.  I also co-lead their tobacco research program as part of the Hollings Cancer Center.  I've been at the medical university since October of 2011.  Before that I spent 31 years at Roswell Park Cancer Institute in Buffalo, New York.

I oversee the tobacco cessation research and treatment programs at the university.  So we have a hospital-based service that I have put into place. Every patient that comes into our hospital is screened for their tobacco use.  If they're a tobacco user, we have a bedside counselor who will, you know, go meet with the patient, and then we follow the patients after they are discharged.

We have similar programs that we put in place for the emergency department, our dental school, and now we're sort of expanding into our outpatient clinic.  So every patient that comes to our institution will, you know, as a standard of care, get treated for their tobacco use.

Did you work on a number of Surgeon General's Reports on smoking and health?

A.   I have.

Q.   And in what capacity, Dr. Cummings?

A.   Well, usually three capacities:  One, you can be a reviewer; number two, you can be asked to contribute and write sections of the report; number three, you can do both of those things.

So I've done all three of those.  So I've been asked to contribute.  I've been asked to review.  And, in some instances, like the 2014 report and the 2012 report, I was asked to not only contribute sections but to review the entire report at the end to provide feedback to the Surgeon General's office prior to its release.

Q.   And I don't want to go through each of these, Doctor, but the NCI specifically you're listed as committee chair for the NCI commit study.

Can you describe to the jury what the commit study is?  What it involved?

A.   Sure.  It's community intervention trial for smoking cessation.  It was really geared towards heavy smokers.  So people smoking 25 or more cigarettes per day are defined as heavy smokers.  They tend to have the greatest burden of disease related to cigarette use.

And so this was a -- a randomized trial.  It was quite unique because they randomized 11 pairs of communities.  So 22 communities in North America.  11 of them got randomized to have an intervention.  That went on between the late 1980s and up to around 1994.

And then the other group was a control, and we created cohorts of smokers; in other words, we sampled smokers, and then we followed them over time and then observed whether our interventions, which went on with doctors and workplaces and the mass media, were having an impact on changing the smoking behavior of the people that were surveyed.

So we selected random samples of smokers in these communities.  And it was a large study, over 22,000 people in the -- in the survey.  I was a PI of one of the institutions that sort of created the trial and ran it.  We had two communities in New York. Binghamton and Utica, New York, were the committees I ran, but I also chaired the evaluation committee which put out all the papers and devised, really, the strategy

Q.   And did that include studying nicotine addiction and cessation among these 22,000 smokers?

So we can look at average annual quit rates. About 3 to 4 percent of smokers are successful in quitting in any given year; how many people overall attempted to quit, which is just about everybody.  Most quit and fail.

So a lot of the data that we have today on indicators of dependence and so on, a lot of it comes from studies that we -- from this particular trial because it was such a large study.  It's not the only

Q. I wanted to briefly mention, Dr. Cummings, in your qualifications, editorial boards and journals for which you act as a reviewer or have acted as a reviewer.

And we see those listed here, including the Journal of Cancer, Nicotine and Tobacco Research, The Journal of Addictive Behaviors, Lancet, The Journal of the American Medical Association.

Can you describe just very briefly what it means to be a reviewer for a journal like this?

A.   Sure.  You're sent an article by the editor of the journal, and they ask you, as a peer reviewer, to give a critique back to the authors and a recommendation back to the editorial board as to whether the paper merits funding, revisions, or acceptance.

And that's -- they typically will send out papers to three or four reviewers to get their opinions so they can get sort of a cross-section of, you know, whether, you know, this is just an outstanding paper and everybody agrees or everybody dis- -- you know, agrees that it's terrible and it shouldn't be published or something in between.

And so that's the -- that's the way we try to

advance science.  You know, it's the job of the peer reviewers:  The topic novel?  Are the methods appropriate?  Are the conclusions, you know, valid and not overreaching?

And, you know, you provide comments back, and then the editorial board makes decisions ultimately on what papers get accepted and which ones do not.

And that's -- try to usually get three or four requests to review every week.  It's part of the process.  So I've served on editorial boards on the other side, you know, like, searching for people who will take the time to give you reviews.  You don't get

Q.   You've also received grants and contracts; is that correct?

A.   Sure.  You know, it's publish or perish, but really it -- you know, on a research job, it's get grant funding or perish.  You're always writing grants, and it's part of the way to build science.  And I've been very successful with my grant funding.

I've been funded from the National Cancer Institute continuously since 1983.  So -- and have probably received about 70 or so grants from various funding agencies.  Mostly from the National Institutes of Health, American Cancer Society, Robert Wood Johnson Foundation.

But most of it comes from the federal government, which funds our -- our -- most research that's done in the -- in the country on all health topics.

A.   Yes.  And, you know, just to be clear, those grants don't come to me.  You write them on behalf of your institution.  So when I was at Roswell Park, the grants came to Roswell Park.  And as the principal investigator of that grant, you would manage the research and the budget around it.  And same is true with the medical university where I am now.

So those grants go to the institutions.  You manage the science that's outlined in the research plan that's presented there.

And it's a very competitive process to get these grants.  You're always writing grants, and you're very happy when you get one funded.  I think they're funding now about 1 out of -- 6 out of 100 grants at the federal level.  So, you know, 94 of those grants go into rewrite or give up, and the other 6 are funded.

So they're -- it's a very highly competitive process to get the grant funding.

A.   My own experience and my own research.  We followed tens of thousands of smokers and looked at what they said initially as to whether they were motivated to quit smoking.  How motivated are you to quit smoking? Are you going to quit smoking in the next month or six months?

Q.   If motivation to quit does not predict permanent cessation, what is the best predictor of permanent cessation?

A.   It's how addicted somebody is.  And our best measure of how addicted somebody is to nicotine is measured by the Heaviness of Smoking Index, which is a two-item scale that is -- that represents two questions: How much you smoke per day and time to first cigarette of the day.

And those two items -- it sounds simple and been called for hundreds of other items that have been tried.  Those two items are very effective at measuring

Q.   I want to point out something that's been pointed out previously in the trial.  Even if you score a zero on the Heaviness of Smoking Index, would you still have some level of addiction according to this metric?

A.   Yeah, of course.  This is a test that's used for people who are persistent daily smokers.  You don't do the Heaviness of Smoking test for people who aren't smoking on a routine basis.  Most people are persistent daily smokers.  If you are, then we apply the Heaviness of Smoking Index to see how dependent you are.

If you score in the high -- you know, a dependence category of high addiction 5 or 6, you're going to have a harder time to quit than somebody who is in the, you know, mild addiction.  So even somebody who is smoking a cigarette a day probably has some dependence, but it's probably at a low level.

A.   Yeah.  Time to first cigarette turns out to be the strongest of the predictors, if you had to pick one, and the reason for that is pretty obvious.  Amount smoked per day is dictated by a lot of factors external to the individual, like how much money you can afford to spend on cigarettes, where you can light them up.  That has impact on number of cigarettes per day.

But time to first cigarette -- if you're smoking first thing before you plant your foot on the floor in the morning, you're addicted.  If you're smoking just before you go to bed at night, if you're waking up in the middle of the night to have a cigarette, these are all strong indications of heavy dependence, and those people need more help.  Standard therapies like nicotine patches and gum probably don't work very well.  You probably need more than that to be successful in quitting.

Some people are more susceptible to be addicted to a substance and others are not, which explains why some people can get away being social smokers.

Q.   And, Dr. Cummings, is wanting to smoke different from needing to smoke?

It's not easy to do, and their brain has been altered.  That's the definition.  You know, it's a chronic relapsing brain disease.

And then began to use the manmade tobacco, reconstituted tobacco, where they would add various pH modifiers to the product.  And in particular, in the mid-'60s they began to use various pH modifiers that gave more impact to the nicotine.  And, you know, things like various ammonia compounds and so on were added to the recon tobacco that was used, and that really was one of the reasons that Marlboro sales took off.

So it's part of the research that I do.  It's part of the teaching that I have done to graduate students to try to, you know, help them understand how to design, you know, communications campaigns to promote, you know, public health efforts.

Q.   And does this document, and as you've just described, the -- the text that's up here on the screen, relate to these health perceptions of -- or individuals' perception of health messaging?

A.   Yes.  Dr. Fishbein basically said you need to give the people different kinds of information.  You really have to understand when you assess what people know and believe and how those beliefs likely relate to behavior, three levels or three categories of -- of belief.  And the first level is awareness.

So people might be exposed, be aware that there's an issue that's being discussed in the media and so on, and such as, you know, the Surgeon General's talking about smoking being bad.  You know, you might have heard something about that.  That doesn't mean that you believe it.

The next level is general acceptance.  These are questions that you might see in polls that are done. A person, you know, may believe that cigarette smoking is dangerous to their health.  Okay?  Or maybe they

Veritext Legal Solutions 212-279-9424                                     www.veritext.com                                    212-490-3430

don't hold that belief.  But you would want to assess that belief.

It's a general acceptance, because it doesn't say that your smoking will affect your health.  And that's the third level, which is a personalized acceptance.  A person may believe that my cigarette smoking is dangerous to my health.  And, you know, what Dr. Fishbein and what the science in this area shows, which is pretty common sense, is the closer you get to personalized belief, the more effect that it has on behavior.  General awareness, hearing about something, really is meaningless.  But it's the first level of communication.  You've got to get somebody to at least hear about the topic.

You -- then you've got to persuade them to come to certain beliefs and then you have to have those beliefs accepted.  And it's really when people begin to accept the -- the belief that smoking is hazardous to their health that you're going to see more change.

And he was doing this in the context of trying to -- he had been commissioned to try to look what the public knows and believes about the effects of cigarette smoking.  And they subsequently did a more detailed analysis that came out a few years later. Q.   Is that the 1981 FTC Report?

A.   Well, it's -- actually, direct marketing campaigns are ways to build loyalty to keep you smoking that brand.  They often will send you coupons for the brand. study evidence on the health hazard of smoking was accumulating in the early 1950s.  This caused concern to the companies; and, in fact, their cigarette sales dropped for the first time in 1953.  First time since the Great Depression.

A.   Well, it turns out now that we have all the documents there were two type of research that got funded:  There was research that came in, was vetted by the scientists through the scientific advisory board through peer review.  Just like they do it in the government and so on.

And then there were these category of projects that were -- didn't go through that process.  They were both -- they were funded by CTR.  But they were really selected by lawyers.

They would have ad hoc committees, lawyers from the different companies.  They might invite ad hoc members like scientists, research directors for the companies.  They would go out and recruit scientists to basically do research that was of interest to the company specifically.

So it was -- the special projects became a major component of CTR of -- really from 1964 onward to try to counter some of the information coming out about the health risks of smoking.  It didn't go through peer review; it wasn't really selected or vetted by the scientists.  And it was not something that was consistent with what was said in the Articles of

After 1958, when the Tobacco Institute was created, it -- it was the communications committee.  It was spun off and that's what became the Tobacco Institute.

And, in fact, you can see exactly the budgets. The budget for TIRC was reduced by the amount of money that went into the Tobacco Institute.  And then from 1950 on, to the end of 1998, you see about ten times as much money going to the Tobacco Institute than you do to the research part of the business.

THE COURT:  With regard to the Noerr-Pennington issue, in O'Hara I had the instruction No. 18 that talked about the manufacturers' appearances before Congress and various regulatory agencies.  And I said that under the law, the manufacturer has the right to petition, provide information and express its views to the government on the issue of policy and legislation concerning smoking and health.

These and similar communications with the government, advocacy efforts and government submissions are protected under the First Amendment to the United States Constitution as well as Florida law.

However, false, misleading, or deceitful statements and representations are not protected under the First Amendment.

Certainly if there is a request for a curative instruction for the jury to understand that, there is no -- it's not appropriate to punish for exercising one's right to petition the government.

What happened in 1964 that would -- you could attribute that drop to?

A.   Well, the Surgeon General's Report came out in January, January 11th of 1964, and was big news.  Got a lot of coverage on all the major TV and networks and newspapers and so on.

And there was a drop in cigarette sales for about two months, when the month of January and February sales had declined, but then had rebounded again in March.

So there was a slight drop.  People were trying to refrain from smoking.  And most ended up going back to smoking again.

A.   Sure.  It was, you know, certainly public knowledge.  Actually, the report came about because John F. Kennedy was asked about -- President Kennedy was asked about a report out of Great Britain in 1962 at one of his press events.  And that report out of Great Britain had concluded that smoking caused cancer, much like the Surgeon General's Report would later say.

And President Kennedy basically said, "I don't know anything about the report, but I'll have somebody look into it."

Two weeks later they announce -- Luther Terry, who was the Surgeon General, announced the formation of the committee, that would be impartial, to look at the evidence.  And that began in 1962, in -- in the spring, actually, in June, and then they began to deliberate and gather evidence.

And there were ten scientists who were the advisory committee to the Surgeon General, that reviewed the evidence and then published it as the report which came out in January.

It was actually supposed to come out in November of that year, but because President Kennedy was assassinated, they delayed the issuing of the report until January.

Who was the Tiderock Corporation?

Q.   And according to this document, Dr. Cummings, how did they go about carrying out this campaign to reestablish the cigarette controversy?

A.   Well, the -- basically they outline a plan to reach the general public, the, you know, opinion leaders who said the program must be massive to counter the pressure from the Clearinghouse.  The Clearinghouse was the government agency that put out the Surgeon General's Reports which, after 1965, were mandated to come out on an annual basis.

And so they're talking in terms of counteracting this program needed to exceed 50 million a year, and then they go forward and outline in this proposal how to go about doing this with getting -- you know, reestablishing the cigarette controversy, putting out an annual white paper that would come out -- and, in fact, that did happen from 1968 to '84.  Every year you got the white papers, just like the original one from '60 -- or from '54 called "The Cigarette Controversy." So if you ever wrote to the Tobacco Institute, they'd send you their white paper, which was like --designed as a Q&A, you know.  "Does cigarette smoking

Q.   And, Dr. Cummings, would the white papers, like the '68 cigarette controversy, be distributed to the --the public, to opinion leaders, as we saw in -- in accordance with the Tiderock plan?

A.   Yes.  They would often highlight people within them, like, "Leading scientists challenge the evidence." In fact, I think in 1968 they highlighted Harry Greene, the pathologist from Yale University.  He was the only person who disputed the evidence that cigarette smoking caused cancer back in 1958.

Q.   And was Philip Morris money and other tobacco company money used to fund all of this work?

A.   Yes.  Extensively.  As I said, the TI budgets increased dramatically.  And particularly in this period, right after 1964, they started to spend more money on public relations, hiring outside companies like Tiderock to produce these materials for them, as well as hiring individuals, public relations specialists who travel around the country and speak on behalf of the companies.

This, in summary, is what the committee says: Cigarette smoking is a major cause of lung cancer in men, and data on women smokers points the same way. Cigarette smoking is a significant cause of cancer of the lungs and probably the most important cause of bronchitis.  Cigarette smoking may be related to other lung diseases.

Male smokers have a much higher death rate from heart disease, although it's not proven that smoking is the cause.  On the question of filters, the committee says there is no evidence that they do any good, but it didn't exclude the possibility that a filter might be developed.

In short, the committee says, "If you smoke cigarettes, you increase your chances of dying early.  The sooner you start, the more you smoke, the more you inhale, the worse your cancers are."

Above all, every American who smokes and every American youngster who is thinking of smoking must now consider whether to stop or not to start.  It comes down to a subjective question. THE WITNESS:  Sure.  Well, upregulation, really talking about the development or growth of new receptors in the brain.

So we all have nicotine receptors whether we smoke or not in our bodies. When people begin to expose themselves to cigarette smoke and they get the nicotine hitting the brain, they develop a need to have more nicotine that reflects the fact that they are growing new receptors, and that's referred to as upregulation of the receptors.

So the brains of smokers are different than the brains of nonsmokers.  They have more of these receptors.

The second part of that question upregulation and --

THE COURT:  And when or how long it takes for it to return to normal once a person quits smoking.

THE COURT:  Mr. Geraghty.

MR. GERAGHTY:  I'll just be very brief, Your Honor.  The issue in this case is we dispute whether he was addicted, Mr. Danielson, and whether the addiction was the legal cause.

There's no dispute that the man had lung cancer and that the lung cancer was the medical cause of his death.

Legal cause in this case relates to addiction and addiction causation.  That's what the Allen case says very, very clearly.  There's a whole discussion of that.  That's what's in dispute.

Dr. Burns wants to talk about how cancer grows and all that kind of stuff.  I think it is completely irrelevant.  And all of these slides are cum- -- I don't think I heard them say that they didn't touch on all these issues with Dr. Hurt and Dr. Cummings.

So I won't belabor the point any more.

maybe bum cigarettes, at least in your high school days.

And, you know, during our high school days, people would hang around the pool hall, and you'd see Vietnam veterans coming in.  They had a cigarette.  I think that, you know, you could even go back today and look at old videos of Vietnam.  It seems like every picture that you see -- that I see, all of them have people smoking in them.  And, you know, it was kind of the Ray-Ban sunglass era, and the -- the -- the Marlboro cigarettes.

And for me, it was -- it was a fad.  I mean, it was not something that -- that I knew I should be doing. It was just something I did.  And I think we -- Lamar and I did it.
